title: Equidecomposable magmas
abstract:
A magma is called equidecomposable when the operation is injective, or, in
other words, if $x+y=x'+y'$ implies that $x=x'$ and $y=y'$. A magma is free iff
it is equidecomposable and graded, hence the notion of equidecomposability is
very related to the notion of freeness although it is not sufficient. We study
main properties of such magmas. In particular, an alternative characterization
of freeness, which uses a weaker condition, is proved. We show how
equidecomposable magmas can be split into two disjoint submagmas, one of which
is free. Certain tranformations on finite presentations permit to obtain a
reduced form which allows us identify all the finite presented equidecomposable
magmas up to isomorphisms.
